mwe.title: MWE-004: Sending Ether to Arbitrary Destinations
mwe.description: When we use function `call` to send ether, the target address should be carefully checked, and an arbitrary address may lead to exploitability.
mwe.recommendation: Ensure that an arbitrary user cannot withdraw unauthorized funds.

mwe.title: MWE-055: Signature Malleability
mwe.description: Implementing a cryptographic signature system in Ethereum contracts often assumes that the signature is unique. However, signatures can be altered without possessing the private key and still be valid. The EVM specification defines several so-called `precompiled` contracts, one of which is `ecrecover`, which executes the elliptic curve public key recovery. A malicious user can slightly modify the three values v, r and s to create other valid signatures. A system that performs signature verification on the contract level might be susceptible to attacks if the signature is part of the signed message hash. A malicious user could create valid signatures to replay previously signed messages.
mwe.recommendation: A signature should never be included in a signed message hash to check if the contract has processed previous messages.

mwe.title: MWE-056: Write to Arbitrary Storage Location
mwe.description:
A smart contract's state variables are persistently stored at some storage location named slot on the EVM level. The contract ensures that only legitimate operations can write to sensitive storage locations.
- However, under the Solidity 0.6 version, this restriction can be circumvented caused by the length of an array is capable of modifying. Primarily the result of the underflow of the length of an array whose type is unit is extremely large. So that arbitrary storage is accessible. Hackers can illegitimately modify state variables by elaborately calculating their location.
mwe.recommendation:
As general advice, given that all data structures share the same storage (address) space, one should make sure that writes to one data structure cannot inadvertently overwrite entries of another data structure.
- particularly, do not modify the length of an array.

results.show_title: MWE-056: Write to Arbitrary Storage Location in contracts/core/sdlPool/SDLPoolSecondary.sol

mwe.title: MWE-100: Possibility of Price manipulation with Balances
mwe.description:
Potential price manipulation risk:
	- In function withdraw
		-- toWithdraw = balanceOf(_account) (contracts/core/StakingPool.sol#104) have potential price manipulated risk from toWithdraw and call None which could influence variable:toWithdraw
mwe.recommendation: It is recommended to use the chainlink oracle to obtain data, or to avoid relying on easily manipulated variables, or to use the TWAP mechanism.

results.show_title: MWE-100: Possibility of Price manipulation with Balances in contracts/core/StakingPool.sol

mwe.title: MWE-100: Possibility of Price manipulation with Balances
mwe.description:
Potential price manipulation risk:
	- In function _updateReward
		-- toMint = balanceOf(_account) - super.balanceOf(_account) (contracts/core/test/deprecated/RewardsPoolV1.sol#79) have potential price manipulated risk from toMint and call None which could influence variable:toMint
	- In function withdraw
		-- toWithdraw = balanceOf(_account) (contracts/core/test/deprecated/OwnersRewardsPoolV1.sol#51) have potential price manipulated risk from toWithdraw and call None which could influence variable:toWithdraw
mwe.recommendation: It is recommended to use the chainlink oracle to obtain data, or to avoid relying on easily manipulated variables, or to use the TWAP mechanism.

results.show_title: MWE-100: Possibility of Price manipulation with Balances in contracts/core/test/deprecated/RewardsPoolV1.sol and other 1 file

mwe.title: MWE-106: Transfer in Loop
mwe.description: The use of the transfer function in Ethereum smart contracts can potentially lead to a DOS (Denial-of-Service) attack, as it automatically reverts the entire transaction if there isn't enough gas for the called contract, possibly locking funds.
mwe.recommendation: To avoid DOS attacks, use the send or call.value functions instead of transfer, as they allow for better error handling by not reverting the entire transaction when the called contract fails due to insufficient gas.

mwe.title: MWE-087: Uninitialized Local Variables
mwe.description: A local variable is either never initialized or is initialized only under certain conditions, while the variable will be used regardless of its initialization. As a result, the default zero value is used, which is not desired.
mwe.recommendation: Initialize the local variable to a reasonable value. Explicitly setting it to zero if it is meant to be initialized to zero.

mwe.title: MWE-088: Unused Return Value
mwe.description: Either the return value of an external call is not stored in a local or state variable, or the return value is declared but never used in the function body.
mwe.recommendation: Ensure the return value of external function calls is used. Remove or comment out the unused return function parameters.

mwe.title: MWE-051: Missing Input Validation
mwe.description: In solidity, there is no "null" equivalent. So we should know every default value for different value types. Meanwhile, we should validate the value passed to state variable. So, for example, when we assign an address type, we should check the value to ensure it's not a zero address.

mwe.title: MWE-084: Possible Usage of a Variable before Declaration
mwe.description: Detects the possible usage of a variable before the declaration is stepped over (either because it is later declared or declared in another scope).
mwe.recommendation: Move all variable declarations before any variable usage, and ensure that reaching a variable declaration does not depend on some conditional if used unconditionally.

mwe.description: Boolean constants can be used directly and do not need to compare to true or false.

mwe.title: MWE-052: Missing Error Message
mwe.description: `require` can be used to check for conditions and throw an exception if the condition is not met, in which case the error message provided by the developer will appear. This is why a very descriptive error message is needed.
mwe.recommendation: Adding an error message describing the failed condition.

mwe.title: MWE-0123: Possibility of Price manipulation with Balances
mwe.description:
Potential price manipulation risk:
	- In function withdraw
		-- toWithdraw = balanceOf(msg.sender) (contracts/core/test/deprecated/OwnersRewardsPoolV1.sol#37) have potential price manipulated risk from toWithdraw and call None which could influence variable:toWithdraw
mwe.recommendation: It is recommended to use the chainlink oracle to obtain data, or to avoid relying on easily manipulated variables, or to use the TWAP mechanism.

results.show_title: MWE-0123: Possibility of Price manipulation with Balances in contracts/core/priorityPool/PriorityPool.sol

mwe.title: MWE-076: DoS with Block Gas Limit
mwe.description: When smart contracts are deployed, functions inside them are called, and the execution of these actions always requires a certain amount of gas based on how much computation is needed to complete them. The Ethereum network specifies a block gas limit, and the sum of all transactions included in a block can not exceed the threshold.\nProgramming patterns that are harmless in centralized applications can lead to Denial of Service conditions in smart contracts when the cost of executing a function exceeds the block gas limit. For example, modifying an array of unknown size that increases over time can lead to a Denial of Service condition.
mwe.recommendation: Caution is advised when you expect to have large arrays that grow over time. Actions that require looping across the entire data structure should be avoided.\n If you absolutely must loop over an array of unknown size, then you should plan for it to take multiple blocks and potentially require multiple transactions.

results.show_title: MWE-076: DoS with Block Gas Limit  in contracts/core/test/deprecated/PoolOwnersV1.sol

mwe.title: MWE-045: Unimplemented Functions
mwe.description: Detect functions that are not implemented on derived-most contracts.
mwe.recommendation: Implement all unimplemented functions in any contract you intend to use directly (not simply inherit from).

mwe.title: MWE-117: Unnecessary Public Function Modifier
mwe.description: Detect the public function which can be replaced with external

results.show_title: MWE-117: Unnecessary Public Function Modifier in contracts/ethStaking/EthStakingStrategy.sol

mwe.title: MWE-083: Unused events
mwe.description: The presence of events that are declared but never used in the codebase. They may increase computation costs and lead to unnecessary gas consumption.
mwe.recommendation: Remove unused events or emit them in the right place to avoid negative effects and improve code readability if there is no plan for further usage.

mwe.title: MWE-073: Floating Pragma
mwe.description: An unlocked compiler version like ^0.8.0 in the contract's source code permits the user to compile it at or above a particular version, which leads to differences in the generated bytecode between compilations due to differing compiler version numbers. As a result, compiler-specific bugs may occur in the codebase that would be hard to identify throughout multiple compiler versions rather than a specific one, which can cause ambiguity. Moreover, the contracts may be at the risk of being accidentally deployed using an outdated compiler version which can introduce bugs to affect the contract system negatively.
mwe.recommendation: Lock the compiler version to the lowest version possible so that the contract can be compiled and consider known bugs for the chosen compiler version.

mwe.title: MWE-011: Potential Constant State Variables
mwe.description: Constant state variables should be declared constant to save gas.
mwe.recommendation: Add the `constant` attributes to state variables that never change.

results.show_title: MWE-011: Potential Constant State Variables in contracts/core/StakingPool.sol

mwe.title: MWE-096: Unnecessary Reentrancy Lock
mwe.description: If there has no call in the function, the reentrancy lock is unnecessary and can be replaced by the `require` logic.
